vectorData.altText: 13. Which anatomical region of this lymph node is indicated by A?
That’s right!  ‘A’ is indicating the cortex of lymph node. Notice the pale germinal centers of the secondary lymph nodules. B-lymphocytes and plasma cells populate in this region.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.

Afferent lymph passes through subcapsular (A) and trabecular (B) sinuses where macrophages (C) in the sinuses detect and process antigen for presentation to T cells of the paracortex.
B cells of the cortex, when exposed to their antigen, proliferate and differentiate into plasma cells, which form the germinal centres of secondary nodules in the cortex.
Plasma cells migrate to the medullary cords where they release  their antibodies for distribution via efferent lymph.
